awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Processes that Generate and Maintain Phylogenetic, Genetic, and Functional Diversity of the Freshwater Mussel Holobiont across Multiple Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
The term 'holobiont' is used to refer to an organism as the sum of the interactions between the host and the microbes associated with them (the 'microbiome'). Yet, the extent to which diversity at different levels of biological organization in host and microbiome communities influence functional diversity within ecosystems represents a considerable gap in our understanding of global biodiversity. This project will represent a landmark in understanding what generates and maintains biodiversity in river ecosystems. Freshwater mussels are a highly imperiled, species-rich group of animals that play critical roles in rivers through their filter-feeding and cycling of nutrients. Although the ecological value of freshwater mussels is widely appreciated, little is known about how factors like genetic diversity of individual species, species composition and diversity of mussel communities, or interactions between mussel communities and their gut microbiomes structure these ecological processes across environments and geographic scales. Similarly, little is known about how host-microbiome interactions have structured the evolution of both groups over time. If the processes and mechanisms underlying patterns of biodiversity in these animals can be identified, managers will be better armed to make informed decisions for conservation and restoration efforts that will ultimately benefit the entire ecosystem. 

Using approaches that scale from individual-to-population-to-species levels and above, this project seeks to understand ecological and evolutionary associations among the environment, genetic diversity, functional traits, and community assembly across both host and microbiome phylogenies in contemporary taxa and ancestral lineages. This research will integrate analyses of (1) intraspecific genetic diversity in a suite of freshwater mussel species, (2) phylogenetic diversity of communities of mussel species as well as their associated microbiomes, and (3) functional diversity of the mussel-microbiome holobiont. Integrating these three dimensions of biodiversity will allow us to comprehend the mechanisms that underpin the roles that freshwater mussels play in ecosystems, and to understand the fundamental ecological and evolutionary processes that structure biodiversity in space and over time. Furthermore, this work will extensively populate public databases with new data on species distributions, abundances, microhabitat environmental characteristics, and DNA sequence variation that will have impacts on basic evolutionary and ecology research while also informing conservation and management of a highly imperiled and ecologically important group.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The extent to which diversity at different levels of biological organization in host and microbiome communities influence functional diversity within ecosystems represents a considerable gap in our understanding of global biodiversity. This project aimed to understand what generates and maintains biodiversity in river ecosystems. Freshwater mussels are a highly imperiled, species-rich group of animals that play critical roles in rivers through their filter-feeding and cycling of nutrients. Although the ecological value of freshwater mussels is widely appreciated, little is known about how factors like genetic diversity of individual species, species composition and diversity of mussel communities, or interactions between mussel communities and their gut microbiomes structure these ecological processes across environments and geographic scales. Similarly, little is known about how host-microbiome interactions have structured the evolution of both groups over time.

This project investigated the linkages among the host microbiome and species identity and multiple metrics of biodiversity spanning the population-, community-, and ecosystem-level in freshwater mussel assemblages. Freshwater mussels are a highly imperiled, species-rich group of animals that play critical roles in rivers through their filter-feeding and cycling of nutrients. Although the ecological value of freshwater mussels is widely appreciated, little has been investigated regarding factors how genetic diversity of individual species, species composition and diversity of mussel communities, or interactions between mussel communities and their gut microbiomes structure ecological processes across environments and geographic scales. Over the course of this project, 22 sites across seven rivers were sampled and 65 species of freshwater mussels were encountered.

The first major finding of this grant is that freshwater mussel population genomic structure is highly structured by river basins and connectivity among rivers. Importantly, there were positive relationships between genomic diversity within a species and density of that species, but no robust support for the expectation of correlated genomic and overall species diversity. The research highlighted the among-species variability in relationships among these different levels of organization.

The second main result is related to what structures the microbiome of freshwater mussels. Overall, freshwater mussels have a core microbiome that is shaped by taxonomic identity as well as the environment and co-occurring mussel species. The research conducted under this grant also showed that there is potential in using ethanol-preserved museum specimens to look at past microbiomes of freshwater mussels. Generally, the findings show that the mussels have a core gut microbiome, but it shifts in response to new environments providing insights into conservation strategies that involve species reintroductions.

The third main result focuses on diversity across levels spanning genomic, species, and functional diversity across communities. Using data that spanned all sampling sites, we find positive correlations between mussel density and species richness, species richness and the number of imperiled species, species richness and community-wide genomic diversity, and species richness and functional richness. However, we did not find any relationship between genomic diversity and functional diversity. Results from genomic sequencing are also assisting with clarifying taxonomic uncertainty in several common mussels in these rivers. These findings have implications regarding conservation targets for this taxonomic group.

The fourth main finding indicated niche partitioning in species-rich mussel communities resulting in different mussel species having different functional roles in river ecosystems. Specifically, mussels use different microhabitats and assimilate different food resources. This suggests that more species-rich communities results in higher ecological functioning, but common species can play a dominant role in functioning. Collectively, this indicates both dominant species and rare taxa can be important for the healthy functioning of ecosystems.

Three graduate students, a postdoc, and more than ten undergraduate student researchers have received training at the University of Alabama in aquatic ecology, molecular biology and genomics, mollusk identification, and computational biology. The project also resulted in a permanent installment and exhibit at the University of Alabama that highlights the diversity of freshwater fauna in the state of Alabama and the ecological and cultural significance of mussels for people. Other significant outreach activities to broaden public awareness regarding freshwater conservation and the significance of freshwater mussels included creation of educational materials for use at public outreach events, outreach lectures, and work with local conservation partners contributing significant broader impacts to freshwater and mollusk conservation.
